subject: Home & DIY
title: Why Old Houses Sag in the Middle
description: A quick win: understand Why Old Houses Sag in the Middle.

hook.text: If a marble rolls to the center of your floor, your house has a sagging problem. It's incredibly common in older homes.

buildup.text: Floor joists span wall to wall. Without a center beam, gravity slowly deflects them downward in the middle.

discovery.text: Wood beams also creepâ€”they slowly deform under constant load. A beam that was straight in 1940 may bow 2 inches by 2024.

twist.text: Sagging floors are usually annoying, not urgent. But they can signal a failing beam or rotted support post below.

climax.text: Jacking a sagging floor level must go slowlyâ€”1/8 inch per monthâ€”or you'll crack plaster, break pipes, and jam doors.

punchline.text: Gravity never stops pulling your house down.

quiz.question: Why must a sagging floor be raised back to level very slowly?
options: Raising it too fast can crack plaster, break pipes, and jam doors
The wood needs time to absorb moisture and expand
Building codes require a month-long inspection period
